Breast Cancer Classification

January 15, 2018

Background

I made this model to test how easily I could use external datasets to create and train a neural network with Google’s TensorFlow library. In this post I’ll attempt to explain the code, its results, and its accuracy. The entire program is in my NeuralNetwork repository on GitHub as well as at the end of this post.

The Training Data

All the training data comes from the Wisconsin Breast Cancer Data Set, hosted by the University of California’s Machine Learning Repository.

The training data consists of 569 subjects each with 3 values (mean, worst value, and standard error) for each of 10 categories:

Read more

Binary Prefixes

January 5, 2018

Decimal Prefixes

When dealing with very large or very small amounts, it is common to append, or rather prepend, one of the SI (metric system) prefixes to whatever unit is being used. For example, the average human weighs $62000\text{g}$ but because that number is cumbersome to use, we usually append kilo- (the SI prefix meaning a thousand) to the gram unit and say $62\text{kg}$ instead.

This system works just fine for all sorts of units of measure like mass, length, energy, etc. But when it’s applied to units of information, specifically binary ones like bits and bytes, a problem arises…

Read more
